content: Dear Mr. President, I have already sent correspondence to Congressmen and Senators regarding this. Their answer is: “I’m sorry but I cannot help you with “Department of Veterans Affairs Policy”. Here is my “Dilemma” I am currently out of work. I have worked for the Federal Government for almost 15 (dedicated) years. I am a retired US Navy Veteran (25 years) of honorable service. After retirement, I went to work for the Department of Defense, Marine Corps Base, Camp Pendleton. I started working as a GS-1173-4/5/7. This was an “upward mobility” position. It was a wonderful job. I worked there for almost 9 years. I worked my way up from a GS-1173-4 to a GS 1173-7 (step 10). Step ten was/is the highest step you can achieve as a GS employee. I worked hard to get to that step. I always wanted to work for the Department of Veterans Affairs…and the only way I figured was to go back to school. I went to school and learned “medical terminology” and “medical administration”. Upon completing this course. I applied for a job with the Veterans Hospital in “Reno” Nevada. I had been out of work for almost 20 months (going to school). I was hired as a GS-0303-5/6. When I started working, Human Resources told me “because I worked in Civil Service before….”their” policy was to attempt to pay at the highest pay held at a previous job. Even though I was not working for the past 18 months…they started me at a GS-0303-5 Step 10. Then….once I went through the probationary period, I was promoted to GS-0303-6 and was also given a step 10. After working at the Reno Nevada Veterans Hospital for almost 4 years….my wife and I decided to follow our Grand Children to Texas. We wanted to be close to them. There was a huge VA Hospital in Temple, Texas…where I thought I could get a job. About two years went past….and I finally got a job in Big Spring, Texas. It was a GS-0525-6/7 job. They would not give me a step 10. They said because of me not having the required experience as an accounting technician, they would have to start me at a step 1. After talking with the Human Resources Chief, she finally decided to give me step 7. I tried to talk with the VA Hospital Director…but he refused to see me or talk with me…regarding this issue. Because I needed the job…..I let it be at that. I spoke to the Director of Human Resources from Reno, NV and he told me “its up to the “Local VA Hospital”. There are times…when I feel the Federal Government should not have their fingers in everything….but in this case….there should be a “standard” policy for everyone to follow….not leave it up to the Human Resources Director. To make a longer story as short as possible….I was recently selected for a GS-0303-6 position in Portland, Oregon. I told the hiring person I was a GS-0303-6 step ten…and faxed them proof of this position. The hiring person….said they have a budget and can only hire as a Step 1. I had to turn down the job. I have already sent correspondence to Congressmen and Senators regarding this. Their answer is: “I’m sorry but I cannot help you with “Department of Veterans Affairs Policy”. I applied for another job, this one in New Hampshire. It’s the same job as in Portland, Or., but this time I was hired and offered a “step 10”. I just can’t understand why/how one section of the agency can offer a step 10…and the other only a step 1. Thank you Sir….for listening

title: Employment with Department of Veterans Affairs

content: Pretty common, if you go from place to place or even leave a job and return, you may have to lose some ground too. I was teaching and was at step 12, but decided to go active during Desert Storm. Stayed active for three years making great money but no action and the job was cutthroat, so I decided to go back to teaching. The district pretty much hired me back into my former job, but at step 6 - about a 10,000 dollar cut. Not their job to make you happy - just to cut pennies wherever - - Wandering and Wondering
reply: Pretty common, if you go from place to place or even leave a job and return, you may have to lose some ground too. title: Employment with Department of Veterans Affairs

content: What is your Bus code? If it's 8888 as a 303 go to CPO and protest it. As far as the step, it should follow You from one place to the other. You should know that each Activity within DOD has stringent budget requirements. The look at your performance is key to placement. After that many years you should understand the system. Your KSA's get Ya on a list of a vacancy thats competitive. The selection process is based on your experience as a 303. DOD aint the place to be right now, gotta trim thier budget by 1/4. Get with CPO and look for a job with DOA. Quit dickin around and get stable, Has alot to do with it! Your Congress Person or Senator won't be able to help you. DOD policy rules. As i've said, get with a CPO rep and get it resolved. I walked in as a GS-7 and retired as a GS-12 Remember, Military time counts for certain things. Ya have to buy all those years for retirement. Good Luck! Got money for everything but "VETERANS" Same old story!

content: Robert, I've worked for the feds for over thirty years...... you are allowed to look up and read the rules yourself...... every supervisors office and, they used to anyway, district office has a copy. I have found that it is up to YOU to be sure of the decisions being made are the correct ones, per the regs. They do not intentionally try to screw you.. but how the regs are intrepreted can sometimes be different bettween personnel officers. One Flag......One Heart......One Nation............EVERMORE

content: Dear Mr. President, I have already sent correspondence to Congressmen and Senators regarding this. Their answer is: “I’m sorry but I cannot help you with “Department of Veterans Affairs Policy”. Here is my “Dilemma” I am currently out of work. I have worked for the Federal Government for almost 15 (dedicated) years. I am a retired US Navy Veteran (25 years) of honorable service. After retirement, I went to work for the Department of Defense, Marine Corps Base, Camp Pendleton. I started working as a GS-1173-4/5/7. This was an “upward mobility” position. It was a wonderful job. I worked there for almost 9 years. I worked my way up from a GS-1173-4 to a GS 1173-7 (step 10). Step ten was/is the highest step you can achieve as a GS employee. I worked hard to get to that step. I always wanted to work for the Department of Veterans Affairs…and the only way I figured was to go back to school. I went to school and learned “medical terminology” and “medical administration”. Upon completing this course. I applied for a job with the Veterans Hospital in “Reno” Nevada. I had been out of work for almost 20 months (going to school). I was hired as a GS-0303-5/6. When I started working, Human Resources told me “because I worked in Civil Service before….”their” policy was to attempt to pay at the highest pay held at a previous job. Even though I was not working for the past 18 months…they started me at a GS-0303-5 Step 10. Then….once I went through the probationary period, I was promoted to GS-0303-6 and was also given a step 10. After working at the Reno Nevada Veterans Hospital for almost 4 years….my wife and I decided to follow our Grand Children to Texas. We wanted to be close to them. There was a huge VA Hospital in Temple, Texas…where I thought I could get a job. About two years went past….and I finally got a job in Big Spring, Texas. It was a GS-0525-6/7 job. They would not give me a step 10. They said because of me not having the required experience as an accounting technician, they would have to start me at a step 1. After talking with the Human Resources Chief, she finally decided to give me step 7. I tried to talk with the VA Hospital Director…but he refused to see me or talk with me…regarding this issue. Because I needed the job…..I let it be at that. I spoke to the Director of Human Resources from Reno, NV and he told me “its up to the “Local VA Hospital”. There are times…when I feel the Federal Government should not have their fingers in everything….but in this case….there should be a “standard” policy for everyone to follow….not leave it up to the Human Resources Director. To make a longer story as short as possible….I was recently selected for a GS-0303-6 position in Portland, Oregon. I told the hiring person I was a GS-0303-6 step ten…and faxed them proof of this position. The hiring person….said they have a budget and can only hire as a Step 1. I had to turn down the job. I have already sent correspondence to Congressmen and Senators regarding this. Their answer is: “I’m sorry but I cannot help you with “Department of Veterans Affairs Policy”. I applied for another job, this one in New Hampshire. It’s the same job as in Portland, Or., but this time I was hired and offered a “step 10”. I just can’t understand why/how one section of the agency can offer a step 10…and the other only a step 1. Thank you Sir….for listening

After retirement, I went to work for the Department of Defense, Marine Corps Base, Camp Pendleton. I started working as a GS-1173-4/5/7. This was an “upward mobility” position. You should know that each Activity within DOD has stringent budget requirements. The look at your performance is key to placement. After that many years you should understand the system. Your KSA's get Ya on a list of a vacancy thats competitive. The selection process is based on your experience as a 303. DOD aint the place to be right now, gotta trim thier budget by 1/4. Get with CPO and look for a job with DOA. Quit dickin around and get stable, Has alot to do with it! Your Congress Person or Senator won't be able to help you. DOD policy rules. As i've said, get with a CPO rep and get it resolved. I walked in as a GS-7 and retired as a GS-12 Remember, Military time counts for certain things. Ya have to buy all those years for retirement. Good Luck! Got money for everything but "VETERANS" Same old story!
title: Employment with Department of Veterans Affairs

title: Employment with Department of Veterans Affairs

content: Robert, I've worked for the feds for over thirty years...... you are allowed to look up and read the rules yourself...... every supervisors office and, they used to anyway, district office has a copy. I have found that it is up to YOU to be sure of the decisions being made are the correct ones, per the regs. They do not intentionally try to screw you.. but how the regs are intrepreted can sometimes be different bettween personnel officers. One Flag......One Heart......One Nation............EVERMORE
